qas.question: Where can one expect to find damage on a disc?
How are scratches on a CD fixed?

answers.text: refilling them with similar refractive plastic or by careful polishing

qas.question: What eats at the plastic and aluminum found in CDs?
Where does the fungus Geotrichum candidum originate from?

plausible_answers.text: the label side of a disc
refilling them with similar refractive plastic or by careful polishing

qas.question: How are scratches on the labeled side of a disc fixed?
What causes edges of CDs to be incorrectly sealed?
Where is the metal reflective layer located?

context: CDs are susceptible to damage during handling and from environmental exposure. Pits are much closer to <b5_0>the label side of a disc<b5_0/>, enabling defects and contaminants on <b8_0>the clear side<b8_0/> to be out of focus during playback. Consequently, CDs are more likely to suffer damage on the <a0_0>label side of the disc<a0_0/>. Scratches on the clear side can be repaired by <a1_0><b6_0>refilling them with similar refractive plastic or by careful polishing<b6_0/><a1_0/>. The edges of CDs are sometimes incompletely sealed, allowing gases and liquids to corrode the metal reflective layer and to interfere with the focus of the laser on the pits. The <a2_0>fungus <b7_0>Geotrichum candidum<b7_0/><a2_0/>, found in <a3_0><b4_0>Belize<b4_0/><a3_0/>, has been found to consume the polycarbonate plastic and aluminium found in CDs.
